journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Simple surrogate models to determine total accessibility duration of low Earth orbit sunsynchronous satellites

article-meta.aff: Faculty of New Technologies Engineering, Shahid Beheshti University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Hossein Bonyan Khamseh, Faculty of New Technologies Engineering, Shahid Beheshti University, G. C., 1983963113, Tehran, Iran. Email: H.Bonyan@gmail.com

abstract.p: Short and infrequent access events are inherent characteristics of low Earth orbit sunsynchronous satellites. Furthermore, for such satellites, distribution pattern of access events varies significantly in time. Thus, determination of the metric of total accessibility duration in a given time interval has been a challenge in the field of low Earth orbit satellite systems engineering. In this article, for zero and conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles, surrogate models were developed to determine total accessibility duration of low Earth orbit satellites, based on orbital altitude of the satellite and latitude of the ground segment. For this purpose, concept of repeatability cycle was employed to achieve total accessibility duration in a time-independent manner. Then, a perturbative propagation model was presented to determine pattern of accessibility events and quantify total accessibility duration metric. In order to account for non-zero minimum elevation angles, two distinct approaches were adopted. In the first approach, four modification factors were introduced to modify the surrogate model for zero elevation angle to account for conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles. In the second approach, a dedicated surrogate model was developed to directly determine total accessibility duration for conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles. Numerous examples are examined to verify fidelity of our two proposed approaches. Due to their simplicity, the surrogate models given in this article eliminate the need for professional staff to determine metric of total accessibility duration. The advantage is that considerable saving in required initial staff cost and schedule can be realized, especially in early mission design phases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Short and discontinuous access to the satellite is an inherent characteristic of low Earth orbit (LEO) sunsynchronous missions. To take account of this peculiar access patterns, in our previous work, two access-based metrics were developed, namely total accessibility duration (TAD) and longest accessibility gap (LAG).1 LAG was comprehensively discussed in Bonyan Khamseh and Navabi,2 and here TAD is treated. Accessibility gap and accessibility duration are schematically shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Typical pattern of access to a LEO sunsynchronous satellite.2

As it can be seen from Figure 1, a LEO sunsynchronous satellite is accessible from a ground segment only in a limited portion of its orbit. TAD is sum of all the accessibility durations in a given period of time. As it was discussed in Bonyan Khamseh and Navabi,1 for a fixed amount of data to be transferred between the satellite and its ground segment, TAD directly determines the minimum requirement of communication data rate. According to Shannon–Hartley channel capacity theorem, lower data rates simplify bandwidth requirement and less complicated and thus less expensive components can be used. Also, as communications can be distributed over longer durations, peak power requirements of the satellite are likely to lessen. Thus, lighter and more compact onboard battery units may be used. Therefore, simple and accurate determination of TAD is an important system engineering activity. Particularly, in early mission design phases, the importance of simplicity and accuracy in TAD determination is twofold. First, in early design phases, systems engineers may lack the expertise to deal with any complicated method for determination of system key metrics. Considering extensive design space of satellite orbits and ground segment locations, either professional mission design staff or simple relationships are required for TAD determination. Professional staffs mean higher initial staff cost or possible initial schedule overruns. Thus, simple relationships for TAD determination are appreciated by satellite systems engineers. Second, in early design phases, there usually exist several alternative mission scenarios for which TAD must be determined. To study a number of alternative scenarios, the evaluation technique must be as simple as possible. In accordance with the authors’ experience, any complicated method for TAD determination will be practically abandoned by most satellite systems engineers, and mission design teams.

Determination of TAD metric and similar related concepts has been addressed by previous literature, to considerable extent. In the following, some outstanding works3–16 are presented, with the purpose of illustration. A prominent work in this area is from Lo3–5 in Jet Propulsion Laboratory proposing use of ergodic theory to quantify TAD metric.3–5 The method proposed by Lo eliminated necessity of integrating differential orbit equation over time and thus significantly improved computational costs. Also, a second advantage of this method is its high fidelity in predicting TAD metric for most satellite and ground segment configurations, except for polar ground segments.3 Based on “the method of ratios”, Negron et al.6 and Alfano and Negron7 developed algorithms to determine mean duration of ground segment access to satellites. That works were extended in Alfano et al.8 to precisely determine rise/set times of a satellite which, in turn, can be employed to evaluate TAD metric. Another important work is by Ali et al. 9,10 who related maximum elevation angle during a satellite pass to accessibility duration but the TAD metric cannot be directly obtained from their work. Also, there are examples of research on the probability distribution function (PDF) of elevation angles11 and satellite presence over a given latitude region12 which can be related to TAD metric. Although some of the reviewed literature can accurately determine TAD metric, there is a common shortcoming in the previous works.

In the previous works, no closed-form solution has been developed for TAD determination. Although Lo3–5 developed a definite integral which can be evaluated to give TAD metric, it cannot be regarded as a closed-form solution. Thus, complicated iterative algorithms must be undertaken for TAD determination. However, the approach for any metric evaluation must be very simple and in terms of basic well-known system parameters, Springmann and de Weck13 and Pritchard14 are excellent examples of such works. Thus, in the area of satellite systems engineering, there is a need for simpler method of TAD determination. Recently, based on a continuous study at a telecommunication research center, Modiri and Mohammady15 and Modiri et al.16 developed a simple closed-from relationship to determine daily TAD metric in LEO sunsynchronous missions. Yet, maximum error of their proposed formula for TAD determination may be as high as 30%, though the mean error is much better.16 In the same work, it was correctly emphasized that the accuracy may only be improved if dependency to date can be excluded from the proposed formula. Also, a serious limitation in the formula in Modiri et al.16 is that it was developed only for zero elevation angle. Thus, for practical communication hardware with non-zero elevation angle, that formula is not applicable.

The contribution of this article is to develop simple closed-form relationships which can be employed to determine TAD metric with higher accuracy compared to previous works. Additionally, based on two distinct approaches, formulas to determine TAD metric for conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles are developed.

The rest of this article is as follows. In “Repeatability cycle for time-independent TAD metric”, the concept of repeatability cycle is employed to cancel out inherent dependency of TAD formulation to date. Then, in “Perturbative method of TAD determination”, the perturbative method of TAD determination is discussed and formulas for TAD determination are developed in “Development of surrogate models”. In “Results and validation”, validity and applicability of our proposed formulas are investigated. Also, comparison with previous works is given for illustration.

sec.title: Repeatability cycle for time-independent TAD metric
sec.p: As discussed by Modiri and Mohammady15 and Modiri et al.,16 accuracy of TAD determination may only be improved if dependency to date can be excluded from the proposed formula. In Bonyan Khamseh and Navabi,1 it was discussed that concept of repeatability cycle can be employed to obtain access-based metrics, such as TAD, in a time-independent manner. To be self-contained, a short description of this concept is given here.

Pattern of ground segment access to a LEO satellite varies with time, i.e. different access pattern for different days. The drawback of this inherent characteristic is that any access-based metric such as TAD will be time-dependent. Yet, after a given time interval, access patterns tend to be identical and access-based metrics may be determined in a time-independent manner. This time interval is often called the repeatability cycle and determined by the following method.

If a satellite completes Rev full revolutions in D days, the longitude difference between each two consecutive ground tracks at the equator, i.e. ΔL will be (1)ΔL=2π*DRe v where ΔL is in radians. It is noted that, in equation (1), D and Rev are dimensionless values of number of days and number of full revolutions in a given repeatability cycle, respectively. On the other hand, ΔL is caused by the Earth rotation and accumulated variation of right ascension of ascending node (RAAN) in each period. Thus (2)ΔL=g(ωe-Ω·g)*Tn In which ωe=7.2925*10-5rads is the Earth’s rotation rate, Ω· the variation rate of RAAN due to J2 effect, and Tn the orbital nodal period, in seconds. Ω· is given by Capderou17 (3)Ω·=-32g(1-e2g)2n0J2g(Reag)2cosi where e is the orbit eccentricity, J2=0.00108263, Re the Earth’s equatorial radius, a the orbit semi-major axis, and i the orbit inclination. Also, nodal orbital period is determined by17 (4)Tn =2πn0+Δ n+ω· where n0=μa3 is the Keplerian mean motion, μ the Earth’s gravitational parameter, Δn the correction term applied to Keplerian mean motion due to variation of mean anomaly, and ω· the variation of argument of perigee due to J2 effect. From17 (5)Δn=34g(1-e2g)32n0J2g(Reag)2g(3cos2i-1g) (6)ω·=34g(1-e2g)2n0J2g(Reag)2g(5cos2i-1g)

Substituting equations (4) to (6) into equation (2) and equating right-hand sides of equations (1) and (2), the number of revolutions in the repeatability cycle is obtained (7)Rev=g(n0+Δn+ω·g)Dωe-Ω· In equation (7), only integer values of Rev give admissible repeatability scenarios. As it can be seen from equation (3), Ω· is a function of orbit eccentricity, semi-major axis, and inclination. Yet, Ω· in sunsynchronous orbits, denoted by Ω·SS, is constant Ω·SS=2π365.26*24*3600=1.9965*10-7rads

By substituting Ω·=Ω·SS in equation (7), repeatability cycle of sunsynchronous orbits can be determined. In this study, time-independent TAD metric for missions with repeatability cycle of 10 days, i.e. TAD10d is obtained. For altitude of 500–1500 km as the LEO region, equation (7) results in 28 repeating scenarios which are given in Table 1. Table 1.
Repeating scenarios with repeatability cycle of 10 days.
Scenario # Number of revolution in 10 days Altitude (km) Inclination (degrees) Scenario # Number of revoultions in 10 days Altitude (km) Inclination (degrees)
1 152 500 97.41 15 138 959 99.30
2 151 530 97.52 16 137 994 99.46
3 150 561 97.64 17 136 1030 99.62
4 149 592 97.76 18 135 1067 99.79
5 148 624 97.89 19 134 1104 99.97
6 147 655 98.01 20 133 1142 100.14
7 146 687 98.14 21 132 1179 100.33
8 145 720 98.27 22 131 1218 100.51
9 144 753 98.41 23 130 1257 100.70
10 143 786 98.55 24 129 1297 100.90
11 142 820 98.69 25 128 1337 101.11
12 141 854 98.84 26 127 1377 100.31
13 140 888 98.99 27 126 1418 101.53
14 139 923 99.14 28 125 1459 101.75

For any of the scenarios in Table 1, pattern of ground segment access to the satellite will identically repeat after each 10 days. Thus, TAD metric in 10 days, i.e. TAD10d will be time-independent for these scenarios and the difficulty encountered in Modiri and Mohammady15 and Modiri et al.16 is removed. In early mission activities such as mission analysis and budget allocation, TAD10d can be employed to assess mean access time in arbitrary periods (days/weeks). As an example TAD¯1d=110TAD10d In which TAD¯1d indicates mean access time in 1 day. In order to quantify TAD10d, in the next section, a method will be presented to determine pattern of ground segment access to a given LEO satellite.

sec.title: Perturbative method of TAD determination
sec.p: In a previous work,1 numerical solution of the so-called Cowell’s method was used to determine pattern of ground segment access to a LEO satellite. That method can be computationally slow as simulation time is increased to tens of days. In this article, an alternative perturbative method is employed which results in an analytic solution. In this method, Lagrange planetary equations are employed with second-degree gravitational potential function. Lagrange planetary equations can be found in standard orbital mechanics literature such as Capderou.17 To be self-contained, they are adopted from Capderou17 and given in equation (8) (8)g{dadt=1nag(2∂R∂Mg)dedt=1na21-e2eg(-11-e2∂R∂ω+∂R∂Mg)didt=1na21-e2sinig(-∂R∂Ω+cosi∂R∂ωg)dΩdt=1na21-e2sinig(∂R∂ig)dωdt=1na21-e2g(1-e2e∂R∂e-cosisini∂R∂ig)dMdt=n+1na2g(-2a∂R∂a-1-e2e∂R∂eg)g}.

In equation (8), M is the orbit mean anomaly, R the perturbing potential, n=μa3 the mean motion, and ddt the derivative operator. For LEO orbits higher than 500 km, effect of J2 perturbing Geopotential exceeds all other perturbations (such as drag and solar/lunar gravity) by four to six orders of magnitude (104 to 106 times). Thus, it is convenient to consider only dominant J2 perturbing Geopotential. A second-degree perturbing Geopotential takes account of J2 effect and thus is employed here. To obtain the perturbing Geopotential, the following form of Geopotential function is adopted from17 (9)Vg(r,ϕg)=-μrg[1-∑k=2∞g(Rerg)kJkPkg(sinϕg)g] where ϕ is the latitude, Jk are the Earth zonal harmonics, and Pk denotes Legendre polynomials. Legendre polynomials are given by Rodrigues’ formula in Battin18 (10)Pkg(αg)=12kk!d kdαkg(α2-1g)k

If the Geopotential is expanded to second degree, the following form is achieved for the perturbing potential (11)RJ2g(r→g)=-J22μrg(Rerg)2g(3sin2ϕ-1g) where J2 corresponds to the Earth equatorial bulge. From the main orbit prorogation formula, r can be expressed as (12)r=ag(1-e2g)1+ecosϑ where ϑ is the satellite true anomaly. Also, for ϕ, one obtains17 (13)3sin2ϕ-1=32sin2ig[1-cos2g(ω+ϑg)g]-12

By substituting equations (12) and (13) into equation (11), the following is obtained (14)RJ2=-32μRe2a3g(1+ecosϑ1-e2g)3J2g{sin2i2g[1-cos2g(ω+ϑg)g]-13g} If the quantities a,e,i, and ω are considered constant in one revolution, RJ2 is a periodical function of only true anomaly ϑ To obtain an average value of RJ2 denoted by R¯J2, one may write (15)R¯J2=12π∫02πR¯J2dM where M is the orbit mean anomaly. dM is given by (16)dM=r2a21-e2dϑ Substituting equations (12), (14), and (16) into equation (15), one may obtain (17)R¯J2=-32μR2a3g(1-e2g)32J2g(12sin2i-13g)

It is recalled that periodic effects average to zero over one period. Thus, R¯J2 only takes account of secular variations of orbital elements. If equation (17) is substituted into Lagrange planetary equations (equation (8)) and noting that ∂R¯J2∂a=-3aR¯J2, ∂R¯J2∂e=-3e1-e2R¯J2,∂R¯J2∂i=sinicosi12sin2i-13R¯J2, and ∂R¯J2∂M=∂R¯J2∂ω=∂R¯J2∂Ω=0 one may obtain (18)g{a·=0→ag(tg)=a0=ctee·=0→eg(tg)=e0=ctei·=0→ig(tg)=i0=cteΩg(tg)=Ω0-g[32g(1-e2g)2nJ2g(Reag)2cosig]g(t-t0g)ωg(tg)=ω0+g[34g(1-e2g)2nJ2g(Reag)2g(5cos2i-1g)g]g(t-t0g)Mg(tg)=M0+n¯g(t-t0g)g.

In equation (18) n¯=M·=n0g[1+34g(1-e2g)32J2g(Reag)2g(3cos2i-1g)g] With orbital elements determined at any time t, satellite position may be determined in the geocentric inertial frame as (19)r→Sg(tg)=ag(1-e2g)1+ecosϑ(t)g[c11c12c13c21c22c23c31c32c33g]g[cosϑ(t)sinϑ(t)0g] where c11=cosΩcosω-sinΩsinωcosi;c12=-cosΩsinω-sinΩcosωcosi;c13=sinΩsini;c21=sinΩcosω+cosΩsinωcosi;c22=-sinΩsinω+cosΩcosωcosi;c33=-cosΩsini;c31=sinisinω;c32=sinicosω;c33=-cosΩsincosi;c33=cosi; and ϑ(t) is determined from transcendental Kepler’s equation by iterative methods such as Newton–Raphson. For our case of circular orbits, simply ϑg(tg)=Mg(tg). With satellite position determined at any time t, now ground segment position vector in the inertial frame must be determined.

Based on WGS84 model, at a given time t, ground segment (GS) position vector r→GSg(tg) in the inertial frame is given by (20)r→GSg(tg)=g(Rccosϕcosθg(tg)Rccosϕsinθg(tg)Rssinϕg) Also (21)Rc=Rϕ+AltGS (22)Rs=g(1-fg)2Rϕ (23)Rϕ=Re1-g(2f-f2g)sin2ϕ where f=0.00335 is the Earth flattening factor and AltGS the altitude of ground segment above the ellipsoidal surface. Also, θg(tg) is instantaneous angular distance between ground segment location and the Vernal Equinox, measured in equatorial plane. The procedure to determine θg(tg) was discussed in our previous work.1 With r→GSg(tg) determined, position vector of satellite relative to the ground segment r→S_rel_GSg(tg) is (24)r→S_rel_GSg(tg)=r→Sg(tg)-r→GSg(tg) At any given time, satellite is accessible from the ground segment if (25)ɛg(tg)=90-cos-1g(r→S_rel_GSg(tg).r→GSg(tg)rS_rel_GSg(tg)rGSg)≥ɛmin

In equation (25), rS_rel_GS(t) and rGS are magnitudes of r→S_rel_GS(t) and r→GS(t), respectively. ɛmin accounts for minimum elevation constraint, typically 5–10° for commercial communication hardware recommended by Roddy.19 From equation (25), rise/set times of the satellite with respect to a given ground segment may be determined. The duration of each accessibility event is computed by subtracting corresponding access initiation from its termination time. TAD metric, in turn, may be determined by summing up duration of all accessibility events in the given period of time.

sec.title: Development of surrogate models
sec.p: For a satellite in its orbit and a given ground segment, TAD metric in a given period of time may be achieved by the process described in the previous section. To exclude the dependency on date, in reference to the discussion presented in “Repeatability cycle for time-independent tad metric”, TAD is determined for a 10-day period, i.e. TAD10d. To develop a surrogate model for TAD determination, the 28 repeating orbit scenarios given in Table 1 are used. This selection is based on wide applications of these orbits for various missions. Also, 10 uniformly distributed ground segment locations are considered which result in 280 (28 × 10) mission scenarios. In Bonyan Khamseh and Navabi1, Li and Liu,11 Modiri and Mohammady15 and Modiri et al.,16 it was discussed that longitude of the ground segment does not affect the pattern of ground segment access to the satellite. Thus, longitude of all ground segments is arbitrarily chosen to be 30∘E. Latitude of the first ground segment is assumed zero (on the equator) and latitude of other ground segments is increased in +10∘ step in latitude direction so that the 10th ground segment is located in 90∘N, i.e. North pole. Access-based metrics for ground segments with the latitude ±Lat are identical and thus it is enough to study only the northern hemisphere to develop a surrogate model for TAD.1,11 In the next subsections, for the described 280 mission scenarios, TAD metric will be studied for zero and conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles. For non-zero elevation angles, two distinct approaches are undertaken. The first approach is to develop modification factors to adjust zero elevation angle model to account for non-zero elevation angles. The second approach is to directly develop a dedicated surrogate model, based on simulation results of TAD metric. Both approaches are included for illustration and comparison.

sec.title: Surrogate model for zero elevation angle
sec.p:
From the algorithm described in “Perturbative method of TAD determination”, TAD metric was determined with an assumption of zero elevation angle. Results are shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
TAD metric for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with zero elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

As it can be easily seen from Figure 2, TAD metric for LEO sunsynchronous missions varies almost linearly with orbit altitude. Yet, improvement of TAD with ground segment latitude follows a highly nonlinear pattern. It must be noted that the latter pattern was found in previous works such as Modiri et al.16 By the means of curve fitting techniques, it was found that a 6-degree polynomial is an appropriate candidate to follow the highly nonlinear trend of TAD improvement with ground segment latitude. In order to develop a surrogate model, response surface methodology (RSM) is employed. RSM is a collection of mathematical and statistical techniques for surrogate model building. Putting simply, response surface to determine TAD is given by (26)TAD=fg(h,Lg)+ε where h is the orbit altitude, L the absolute value of ground segment latitude, and ε the error present in the model. A multivariate least-square method was employed to obtain f g(h,Lg) in a manner to minimize ε. Based on this method, the following surrogate model is proposed for TAD determination in LEO sunsynchronous missions (27)TAD10d_Elev0=h(3.43*10-10L6-1.85*10-7L5 +1.63*10-5L4-2.53*10-4L3 +3.39*10-3L2+4.81*10-2L +39.1)+1.69*10-7L6

It is reminded that TAD10d_Elev0 is simply TAD metric in a 10-day period with a minimum elevation angle of zero, with the dimension in seconds. For comparison purposes, results of TAD metric obtained from our surrogate model are given in Figure 3. Figure 3.
TAD metric from our model for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with zero elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

Comparing Figure 3 with Figure 2, one may clearly see that trends of TAD metric obtained from our model are very similar to those obtained from actual simulations. Hereafter, for our model, the following relationship is employed to assess the percentage of error in TAD determination (28)εi,j=g(TAD-TADRefTADRefg)i,j* 100 where i and j are the scenario numbers for ground segment location and satellite orbit, respectively. In equation (28), TAD is the value of TAD metric obtained from surrogate model. Here, it is necessary to adopt a method to determine TADRef. It is a common practice to take the results from Satellite ToolKit (STK) software as the reference for comparison purposes. Farahmand20 and Roberts and Roberts21 from California Polytechnic and Cranfield University are good examples that adopt the results from this software as the reference for validation. Here, in compliance with our orbit propagation method, results from STK J2 propagator are taken as the reference for comparison. One must be careful to take account of the minimum elevation angle and total duration of simulation to determine εi from equation (28). As an example, to assess the error of our proposed model to determine TAD in a 10-day time interval for a 5° minimum elevation angle, equation (28) will be εi,j10d_Elev5=g(TAD10d_E lev5-TADRef10d_E lev5TADRef10d_E lev5g)i,j*100

Mean percentage of error of the model is defined as (29)ε¯=∑1NGS∑1NSg|εi,jg|NGSNS where NGS and NS are the numbers of ground segment and satellite scenarios considered in a given study. It is recalled that equation (29) takes account of absolute value of error so that positive and negative errors do not cancel out each other. For comparison purposes, the formula proposed by Modiri et al.16 is given in equation (30) (30)TAD1d=h(-28.56*10-9L4+458*10-8L3 -213*10-6L2+364*10-5L+0.052) +17.88*10-7L4 In which TAD1d the is total accessibility duration for 1 day, in minutes. It is recalled that the formula in Modiri et al.16 only evaluates TAD for zero elevation angle. Validity of equation (27) and that given by Modiri et al.16 is investigated in “Results and validation”.

sec.title: Modification factors for non-zero elevation angle
sec.p:
Here, our model is further extended to account of non-zero elevation angles. Typically, two values of minimum elevation angle are considered in space applications, i.e. 5° for C band and 10° for Ku band.19 The same values are studied here. TAD metric for elevation angles of 5° and 10° was determined by the algorithm given in “Perturbative method of tad determination”. In our first approach, a statistical analysis of the ratio of TAD metric with non-zero elevation angles over TAD metric with zero elevation angle was carried out. Analyzing 280 mission scenarios from which equation (27) was developed, four modification factors were derived to adjust equation (27) to take account of 5° and 10° minimum elevation angles. Results are given in Table 2. Table 2.
Modification factors of equation (27) for elevation angles of 5° and 10°.
Ground segment latitude less than or equal to 60∘ Ground segment latitude more than 60∘
Modification factor (mf5) TADElev5=mf5*TADElev0 0.70 0.78
Modification factor (mf10) TADElev10=mf10*TADElev0 0.49 0.61
TAD: total accessibility duration.

To account for the 5° and 10° elevation angles, TAD metric obtained from equation (27) must be multiplied by the modification factors given in Table 2, based on the latitude of the ground segment. Validity of this approach is examined in “Results and validation”.

sec.title: Direct surrogate model for 5° elevation angle
sec.p:
In this subsection, a dedicated model is developed to determine TAD metric, for 5° elevation angle. It is mentioned that non-zero elevation angles are practical issues due to ground segment neighboring obstacles, atmospheric absorptions, Earth thermal radiation, and the like.19 From the algorithm given in “Perturbative method of TAD determination”, TAD metric was determined with an assumption of 5° elevation angle. Figure 4 illustrates the results. Figure 4.
TAD metric for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with 5° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

Similar to the approach described in “Surrogate model for zero elevation angle”, a surrogate model was developed to determine TAD, according to a multivariate least square method. Result is given by equation (31) (31)TAD10d_Elev5=h(-1.49*10-9L6+2.69*10-7L5 -2.13*10-5L4+1.07*10-3L3 -2.01*10-2L2+1.97*10-1L+27.9) +1.09*10-7L6 where TAD10d_Elev5 is the TAD metric in 10 days assuming 5° elevation angle, with the dimension in seconds. In Figure 5, TAD metric obtained from our model is illustrated for comparison purposes. Figure 5.
TAD metric from our model for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with 5° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Validity of our surrogate model and equation (31) is examined in “Results and validation”.

sec.title: Direct surrogate model for 10° elevation angle
sec.p:
TAD metric was derived from the algorithm given in “Perturbative method of TAD determination”, with an assumption of 10° elevation angle. Results are given in Figure 6. Figure 6.
TAD metric for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with 10° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

Similar to the previous subsection, a surrogate model was derived to determine TAD metric for 10° minimum elevation angle. The resultant formula is given by equation (32) (32)TAD10d_Elev10=h(-6.14*10-10L6+4.71*10-8L5 +2.37*10-6L4-1.33*10-4L3 +3.24*10-3L2+6.57*10-2L +19.8)+5.97*10-8L6 Similar to our previous models, TAD10d_Elev10 is in seconds. For comparison purposes, results for TAD obtained from our model are shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
TAD metric from our model for 280 repeating scenarios in 10 days with 10° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

sec.title: Results and validation
sec.p: Our proposed models were developed from 280 mission scenarios, i.e. 28 repeating satellite scenarios given in Table 1, along with 10 ground segment locations. Often, in surrogate model validation, it is not common to evaluate the model in the scenarios (sampling points) from which it was developed. Yet, in our context, sampling points are repeatable satellite scenarios which are very attractive for many mission designers. Thus, at first, these scenarios are treated. In “Results for random non-repeating satellite scenarios”, random scenarios are discussed too.

Results are given for zero and non-zero elevation angles. For zero elevation angle, results from the model (equation (30)) of Modiri et al.16 are also presented. Maximum and mean percentage of error from equations (28) and (29) are given in each case. In all cases, mean error ≤10 % is considered as a popular criterion for validity of surrogate models.

sec.title: Results for repeating satellite scenarios
sec.p: In this section, 280 mission scenarios corresponding to repeating satellite scenarios are considered. Results are given for zero and non-zero elevation angles.

sec.title: Zero elevation angle
sec.p:
Over the mentioned domain, for zero minimum elevation angle, TAD was determined from equation (27). From equations (28) and (29), maximum and mean percentage of error were obtained. Percentage of error to determine TAD is shown in Figure 8. Over the same domain, TAD was determined by the formula proposed by Modiri et al.,16 percentage of error given in Figure 9. Figure 8.
Error of equation (27) for TAD determination with zero elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Figure 9.
Error of formula by Modiri et al.16 for TAD determination with zero elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.

In Table 3, maximum and mean percentage of error of our proposed formula are compared with that given by Modiri et al.,16 for zero elevation angle. Table 3.
Comparison of equation (27) with that of Modiri et al.16 for repeating scenarios with zero elevation angle.
TAD from equation (27) TAD from Modiri et al.16
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) 3.2 7.1
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) 11.7 26.9
TAD: total accessibility duration.

As it can be seen from Table 3, for repeating scenarios with zero elevation angle, our model and also that of Modiri et al.16 offer acceptable mean errors, i.e. ≤10%. It is highlighted that both mean and maximum percentages of error to determine TAD metric are improved by our work.

sec.title: 5°elevation angle
sec.p:
To determine TAD metric for non-zero elevation angles, in previous sections, two approaches were discussed. For a 5° elevation angle, based on the first approach, i.e. modification factors, error of TAD determination was obtained and shown in Figure 10. Also, error of the surrogate model to directly determine TAD metric with 5° elevation angle, i.e. equation (31) is shown in Figure 11. For both approaches, mean and absolute maximum percentage of error are given in Table 4. It is reminded that the model by Modiri et al.16 cannot be employed to determine TAD with 5° elevation angle. Figure 10.
Error of modification factor approach for TAD determination with 5° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Figure 11.
Error of direct approach for TAD determination with 5° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Table 4.
Comparison of our two approaches for repeating scenarios with 5° elevation angle.
TAD from Modiri et al.16 TAD from modification factor approach TAD from direct approach (equation (31))
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) N/A 4.7 3.6
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) N/A 18.5 20.5
TAD: total accessibility duration.

As it can be seen from Table 4, both our methods to determine TAD with 5° elevation angle offer mean percentage errors less than 5% and thus are good candidates to be employed in early mission design phases.

sec.title: 10°elevation angle
sec.p:
For 10° minimum elevation angle, an analogous procedure for presentation of results is adopted. Figures 12 and 13 illustrate error percentages of our first and second approaches to determine TAD metric with 10° elevation angle, respectively. Also, mean and maximum values of error for TAD determination are given in Table 5. Figure 12.
Error of modification factor approach for TAD determination with 10° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Figure 13.
Error of direct approach for TAD determination with 10° elevation. TAD: total accessibility duration.
Table 5.
Comparison of our two approaches for repeating scenarios with 10° elevation angle.
TAD from Modiri et al.16 TAD from modification factor approach TAD from direct approach (equation (32))
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) N/A 8.6 6.7
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) N/A 33.2 36.9
TAD: total accessibility duration.

As it can be seen from Table 5, both our methods give fine error to determine TAD with 10° elevation angle. Taking account of their simplicity, they are handy tools to be employed in early mission design phases.

sec.title: Results for random non-repeating satellite scenarios
sec.p:
In this section, 100 random mission scenarios consisting of 10 random non-repeating satellite scenarios along with 10 random ground segment locations are studied. Table 6 gives specifications of these random scenarios. Table 6.
Ten non-repeating satellite scenarios along with 10 random ground segment locations.
Scenario # Altitude of the satellite orbit (km) Location of the GS (degrees)
1 1206 56.7∘ E59.0∘ S
2 531 10.6∘ W3.2∘ N
3 777 15.4∘ W 76.4∘ S
4 546 174.7∘ E84.1∘ N
5 597 71.9∘ W 61.1∘ N
6 1323 51.1∘ E 68.2∘ N
7 1195 151.8∘ E 66.9∘ N
8 817 30.3∘ W 35.3∘ S
9 1450 74.8∘ W 59.0∘ S
10 534 14.6∘ 15.4∘ S
In the following, validity of our proposed surrogate models for TAD determination in random scenarios is examined.

sec.title: Zero elevation angle
sec.p:
For zero elevation angle, TAD was obtained from equation (27) and maximum error and mean percentage of error were determined. Results are given by Table 7. Table 7.
Comparison of equation (27) with Modiri et al.16 for non- repeating scenarios with zero elevation angle.
TAD from equation (27) TAD from Modiri et al.16
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) 4.0 5.3
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) 9.8. 15.2.
TAD: total accessibility duration.

From Table 7, mean error of both our formulae and that given by Modiri et al.16 to determine TAD metric are within the acceptable error, i.e. ≤10%. Similar to previous cases, our proposed formula is more accurate than that by Modiri et al.16

sec.title: 5°elevation angle
sec.p:
For non-repeating satellite scenarios with 5° elevation angle, mean error of our two proposed methods is presented in Table 8. Table 8.
Comparison of our two approaches for non-repeating scenarios with 5° elevation angle.
TAD from Modiri et al.16 TAD from modification factor approach TAD from direct approach (equation (31))
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) N/A 9.5 4.7
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) N/A 29.9 18.9
TAD: total accessibility duration.

From Table 8, it is seen that mean percentage of error of our first method is 9.5%. Also, mean error of our second approach, i.e. equation (31) is 4.7%. Mean errors of both of our approaches are within the allowable error for mission design purposes. Yet, the second approach is more accurate and thus it is recommended to be employed.

sec.title: 10°elevation angle
sec.p:
For a 10° minimum elevation angle, the following results were obtained, as shown in Table 9. Table 9.
Comparison of our two approaches for non-repeating scenarios with 10° elevation angle.
TAD from Modiri et al.16 TAD from modification factor approach TAD from direct approach (equation (32))
Mean percentage of error (equation (29)) N/A 18.0 10.0
Absolute maximum percentage of error (equation (28)) N/A 58.9 33.6
TAD: total accessibility duration.

As it can be seem from Table 9, mean percentage of error of modification factors method can be as high as 18.0%, with the maximum error up to 58.9%. These errors are not within the allowable error for surrogate models regarding satellite mission design. Yet, our second method offers a much better accuracy. Mean percentage of error of equation (32) to determine TAD with 10° elevation angle over the 100 random scenarios is 10.0%. This mean error is acceptable and thus, for the 10° elevation angle, it is recommended to employ only our second approach, i.e. equation (32) to determine TAD metric.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: Simple surrogate models were developed to determine TAD metric in LEO sunsynchronous missions, based on satellite orbit altitude and latitude of ground segment. The models proposed in this article improve the accuracy of TAD determination of previous works. In addition to improvement in accuracy, a distinction of our work compared to previous works is that it can determine TAD metric for conventional non-zero minimum elevation angles.

In the 280 repeating mission scenarios from which our surrogate model was developed, the following measures of accuracy were achieved. For zero elevation angle, mean error of TAD determination in previous work was 7.1% and in our work, it was improved to 3.2%. For 5° elevation angle, model from previous work is not applicable. Regarding our models, mean error of modification factor approach was 4.7% and that of direct surrogate model was 3.6%. For 10° elevation, mean errors were 8.6% and 6.7% for modification factor approach and direct model, respectively. For repeating satellite scenarios and with the criterion of mean error ≤10%, both of our approaches are acceptable and can be used in mission design.

In 100 random scenarios investigated, simulation results showed that our model is more accurate compared to previous model. For zero elevation angle, mean error of our model was 4%, while error of previous model was 5.3%. For 5° elevation angle, previous model is not applicable and mean error of the better of our two approaches, i.e. direct surrogate model was 4.7%. For the same case, mean error of modification factor approach was 9.5%. Thus, with the criterion of mean error ≤10%, both approaches are still applicable. For 10° elevation angle, mean error of direct surrogate model was 10% and that of direct approach was 18%. Considering mean error tolerance condition, in this case, only the direct approach is applicable and may be used for mission design.

Due to simplicity and better accuracy of our model compared to the previous one, it can be employed to determine TAD metric, especially in early mission design phases where little expertise may exist in systems engineering and mission design teams. The advantage is that by eliminating the need for professional staff, considerable saving in required initial staff cost and schedule can be realized.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was carried out as part of authors’ personal research. Thus, no funding was received.

def.p: number of days in a given repeatability cycle
number of full revolutions in a given repeatability cycle
position vector of the satellite relative to the ground segment
longitude difference between two consecutive ground tracks at the equator
angular distance between the ground segment location and Vernal Equinox
variation rate of RAAN in sunsynchronous orbits
